payload.instructions:
# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm
- If you want to boot the kernel, the shell has a variety of commands (including shutdown) - which you can use to stop the kernel and return to your thinking
- Always run "make" to check your work before handing back to the user
- Use x86_64-elf-addr2line in order to look for lines in stacktraces in compiled code

Thanks!

<user_instructions>

# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm
- If you want to boot the kernel, the shell has a variety of commands (including shutdown) - which you can use to stop the kernel and return to your thinking
- Always run "make" to check your work before handing back to the user
- Use x86_64-elf-addr2line in order to look for lines in stacktraces in compiled code

Thanks!



</user_instructions>

## My request for Codex:
We're going to dramatically improve the performance of user-side ATK apps:

1. It appears that we're doing way too many repaints of window client areas, even when pixels haven't changed.  An example is the task manager application - my mouse pointer is flickering when I move over this window, even though nothing in the task list is changing.  Design a strategy to ensure that we only repaint when truly necessary, whilst preserving a client apps ability to request a repaint (but determine if it's needed first!).

2. Look at the overall structure and architecture of ATK between the server (kernel) and userland client - examine spots for performance improvement, design a soltuion, and implement it.

payload.output: Plan updated

{"output":"# Userland ATK Applications

This prototype introduces a path for running ATK-based applications in userland while keeping the kernels video/ATK pipeline in control of global state (window chrome, focus, mouse routing) and hardware access.

## Architecture

* The kernel hosts **remote ATK windows** (`user_atk_window_t`). Each remote window is a normal ATK window that owns an `atk_image` child. The image points at a pixel buffer that the user process updates via a syscall.
* New syscalls expose the functionality:
  * `SYSCALL_UI_CREATE`  create a remote window (`user_atk_window_desc_t`).
  * `SYSCALL_UI_PRESENT`  copy a RGB565 buffer from userland into the window image and request a refresh.
  * `SYSCALL_UI_POLL_EVENT`  fetch mouse/key/close events; supports blocking.
  * `SYSCALL_UI_CLOSE`  tear a remote window down.
* `user_atk.c` in the kernel bridges ATKs event handling:
  * `atk_handle_mouse_event`/`atk_handle_key_char` now consult `user_atk_host` helpers. When a remote window sits under the cursor, global focus is updated, window dragging/title-bar operations remain kernel-managed, and a per-window event queue receives content-space events.
  * Mouse capture is honoured so drags continue even if the cursor leaves the window.
  * Closing a window via the title bar emits a `USER_ATK_EVENT_CLOSE` for the owning process.
* When a process exits, all of its remote windows are closed automatically.

## Userland Toolkit

* We compile the ATK sources for userland with `ATK_NO_DESKTOP_APPS` so shared code (window manager, widgets) is available without shell/task-manager dependencies. Rendering helpers (`video_*`) are provided by `user/video_surface.c`, which draws into a software buffer.
* `atk_user.c` wraps the UI syscalls. It owns the software surface, exposes `atk_user_window_open`, `atk_user_present`, `atk_user_wait_event`, and `atk_user_close`, and wires the surface into the ATK renderer.
* Because `video.h` was hard-coded, it now honours `VIDEO_WIDTH`/`VIDEO_HEIGHT` overrides. Userland builds set these constants (currently 640360) so every ATK call uses the same logical surface size that the kernel remote window allocates.
* User apps render exactly like the kernel: they call `atk_render()` after ATK reports a redraw, then push the buffer via `atk_user_present`. Local widgets (text input, label, etc.) behave exactly as they do in kernel space because we instantiate a regular ATK window and slide it upward (negative Y) so the chrome is clipped before blitting into the remote frame.

## Event Model

Global vs. local responsibilities are split:

* **Global**: window chrome, z-order, focus changes and capture continue to live in the kernel ATK state. Mouse presses on titles still drag windows, the desktop still receives clicks, etc.
* **Local**: content-space events (mouse within the client area, key presses when the remote window has focus, close notifications) are delivered to the user process via the new syscalls. The user process feeds them into its ATK state (`atk_handle_mouse_event`/`atk_handle_key_char`) and decides when to redraw.

## Demo

`user/atk_demo.c` is a minimal userland GUI app:

1. Calls `atk_user_window_open` (title ATK Demo) to create a 640360 remote window.
2. Initialises its own ATK state/theme, creates a single ATK window (Y shifted by `-ATK_WINDOW_TITLE_HEIGHT` so only the body is visible), adds a label + text input, and hooks the submit handler.
3. Runs an event loop that waits on `USER_ATK_EVENT_*`, passes mouse/key events into ATK, and redraws/presents whenever ATK sets the `redraw` flag.

The command `useratk` (wired into the shell) launches `/bin/atk_demo`, letting us exercise the full path end-to-end.

Two additional userland binaries are now available:

* `atkshell` launches a graphical shell window backed by the kernels shell session service.
* `taskmgr` opens the ATK Task Manager, showing process and network snapshots gathered via the new syscalls.

payload.text:
**Analyzing redraw triggers and flicker causes**

I'm working through why user-level code redraws entire regions unnecessarily, causing flickeringespecially with remote windows where full repaints happen on simple pointer moves. I want to trace how redraw flags get set in mouse event handling and explore ways to detect actual pixel changes before forcing repaints, possibly by comparing buffers or using dirty rectangles to reduce redundant drawing. I'll also look into the user event loops and specific apps like the task manager to understand where redraws originate.

payload.text:
**Designing repaint optimization strategy**

I'm working through how to avoid unnecessary screen repaints by tracking whether any actual drawing happened, thinking about adding a dirty flag query or changing `atk_render` to return a bool. I want to preserve existing interfaces while enabling userland to only call present functions if the video surface really changed, and I'm inspecting related `video_surface` code to see how to best hook into the dirty state.

payload.text:
**Designing userland repaint optimization**

This is quite the deep dive into how to optimize repainting in the userland ATK apps by tracking dirty state more precisely. Im thinking adding functions in `video_surface.h` to query and consume dirty flags, modifying `atk_render` to return whether anything was drawn, and gating `atk_user_present` calls based on actual surface changes could really cut down unnecessary redraws and remote updates. Its neat how this approach balances letting apps request redraws while avoiding performance hits from repainting unchanged content. Ill focus on designing the API and integrating dirty checks cleanly with minimal disruption to existing kernel and userland call sites.

payload.text:
**Designing surface dirty tracking system**

I'm mapping out a detailed plan to track when video surfaces have been modified, using a generation counter and a dirty flag. This includes updating how drawing functions mark surfaces dirty, gating costly presents if nothing changed, and handling present failures by re-marking dirty to retry later. Also thinking about extending the present API to support forced presents that bypass dirty checks, aiming to optimize performance while preserving client flexibility.

**Implementing forced present and event coalescing**

Im finalizing improvements to allow forced screen presents bypassing the dirty check, adding new functions like `atk_user_present_force`. Im also planning to coalesce consecutive mouse move events in the event queue to reduce overhead, updating various drawing functions to mark surfaces dirty properly, and ensuring existing loops gracefully skip unnecessary renders or presents. This should boost performance and reduce flicker while maintaining compatibility.

payload.text:
**Implementing dirty gating and event coalescing**

I'm planning to add a dirty flag system in `video_surface.c` to track when the surface actually needs repainting, updating related APIs and header files accordingly. Then I'll modify `atk_user.c` to respect this gating by skipping redundant presents unless forced, and introduce an optional force flush API. Additionally, Ill enhance event handling by coalescing consecutive mouse move events without button presses to reduce event queue load, and prepare documentation updates to explain these new behaviors. This should optimize redraw calls and event processing nicely!

This should optimize redraw calls and event processing nicely!

payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: docs/user_atk.md
@@
 * We compile the ATK sources for userland with `ATK_NO_DESKTOP_APPS` so shared code (window manager, widgets) is available without shell/task-manager dependencies. Rendering helpers (`video_*`) are provided by `user/video_surface.c`, which draws into a software buffer.
 * `atk_user.c` wraps the UI syscalls. It owns the software surface, exposes `atk_user_window_open`, `atk_user_present`, `atk_user_wait_event`, and `atk_user_close`, and wires the surface into the ATK renderer.
 * Because `video.h` was hard-coded, it now honours `VIDEO_WIDTH`/`VIDEO_HEIGHT` overrides. Userland builds set these constants (currently 640360) so every ATK call uses the same logical surface size that the kernel remote window allocates.
-* User apps render exactly like the kernel: they call `atk_render()` after ATK reports a redraw, then push the buffer via `atk_user_present`. Local widgets (text input, label, etc.) behave exactly as they do in kernel space because we instantiate a regular ATK window and slide it upward (negative Y) so the chrome is clipped before blitting into the remote frame.
+* User apps render exactly like the kernel: they call `atk_render()` after ATK reports a redraw, then push the buffer via `atk_user_present`. Local widgets (text input, label, etc.) behave exactly as they do in kernel space because we instantiate a regular ATK window and slide it upward (negative Y) so the chrome is clipped before blitting into the remote frame.
+* `atk_user_present()` now consults the software surfaces dirty bit and becomes a no-op when no pixels changed, eliminating redundant copies to the kernel. `atk_user_present_force()` is available when a client needs to push the buffer even if nothing was marked dirty (for example after resyncing window contents).
@@
 * **Global**: window chrome, z-order, focus changes and capture continue to live in the kernel ATK state. Mouse presses on titles still drag windows, the desktop still receives clicks, etc.
 * **Local**: content-space events (mouse within the client area, key presses when the remote window has focus, close notifications) are delivered to the user process via the new syscalls. The user process feeds them into its ATK state (`atk_handle_mouse_event`/`atk_handle_key_char`) and decides when to redraw.
+* The kernel coalesces plain mouse-move events per window, so a client only sees the latest coordinates when the pointer is moving without new presses/releases. This keeps queues short and avoids starving UI threads when the pointer is jittery.
*** End Patch

{"output":"     1	# Userland ATK Applications
     2	
     3	This prototype introduces a path for running ATK-based applications in userland while keeping the kernels video/ATK pipeline in control of global state (window chrome, focus, mouse routing) and hardware access.
     4	
     5	## Architecture
     6	
     7	* The kernel hosts **remote ATK windows** (`user_atk_window_t`). Each remote window is a normal ATK window that owns an `atk_image` child. The image points at a pixel buffer that the user process updates via a syscall.
     8	* New syscalls expose the functionality:
     9	  * `SYSCALL_UI_CREATE`  create a remote window (`user_atk_window_desc_t`).
    10	  * `SYSCALL_UI_PRESENT`  copy a RGB565 buffer from userland into the window image and request a refresh.
    11	  * `SYSCALL_UI_POLL_EVENT`  fetch mouse/key/close events; supports blocking.
    12	  * `SYSCALL_UI_CLOSE`  tear a remote window down.
    13	* `user_atk.c` in the kernel bridges ATKs event handling:
    14	  * `atk_handle_mouse_event`/`atk_handle_key_char` now consult `user_atk_host` helpers. When a remote window sits under the cursor, global focus is updated, window dragging/title-bar operations remain kernel-managed, and a per-window event queue receives content-space events.
    15	  * Mouse capture is honoured so drags continue even if the cursor leaves the window.
    16	  * Closing a window via the title bar emits a `USER_ATK_EVENT_CLOSE` for the owning process.
    17	* When a process exits, all of its remote windows are closed automatically.
    18	
    19	## Userland Toolkit
    20	
    21	* We compile the ATK sources for userland with `ATK_NO_DESKTOP_APPS` so shared code (window manager, widgets) is available without shell/task-manager dependencies. Rendering helpers (`video_*`) are provided by `user/video_surface.c`, which draws into a software buffer.
    22	* `atk_user.c` wraps the UI syscalls. It owns the software surface, exposes `atk_user_window_open`, `atk_user_present`, `atk_user_wait_event`, and `atk_user_close`, and wires the surface into the ATK renderer.
    23	* Because `video.h` was hard-coded, it now honours `VIDEO_WIDTH`/`VIDEO_HEIGHT` overrides. Userland builds set these constants (currently 640360) so every ATK call uses the same logical surface size that the kernel remote window allocates.
    24	* User apps render exactly like the kernel: they call `atk_render()` after ATK reports a redraw, then push the buffer via `atk_user_present`. Local widgets (text input, label, etc.) behave exactly as they do in kernel space because we instantiate a regular ATK window and slide it upward (negative Y) so the chrome is clipped before blitting into the remote frame.
    25	* `atk_user_present()` now consults the software surfaces dirty bit and becomes a no-op when no pixels changed, eliminating redundant copies to the kernel. `atk_user_present_force()` is available when a client needs to push the buffer even if nothing was marked dirty (for example after resyncing window contents).
    26	
    27	## Event Model
    28	
    29	Global vs. local responsibilities are split:
    30	
    31	* **Global**: window chrome, z-order, focus changes and capture continue to live in the kernel ATK state. Mouse presses on titles still drag windows, the desktop still receives clicks, etc.
    32	* **Local**: content-space events (mouse within the client area, key presses when the remote window has focus, close notifications) are delivered to the user process via the new syscalls. The user process feeds them into its ATK state (`atk_handle_mouse_event`/`atk_handle_key_char`) and decides when to redraw.
    33	* The kernel coalesces plain mouse-move events per window, so a client only sees the latest coordinates when the pointer is moving without new presses/releases. This keeps queues short and avoids starving UI threads when the pointer is jittery.
    34	
    35	## Demo
    36	
    37	`user/atk_demo.c` is a minimal userland GUI app:
    38	
    39	1. Calls `atk_user_window_open` (title ATK Demo) to create a 640360 remote window.
    40	2. Initialises its own ATK state/theme, creates a single ATK window (Y shifted by `-ATK_WINDOW_TITLE_HEIGHT` so only the body is visible), adds a label + text input, and hooks the submit handler.
    41	3. Runs an event loop that waits on `USER_ATK_EVENT_*`, passes mouse/key events into ATK, and redraws/presents whenever ATK sets the `redraw` flag.
    42	
    43	The command `useratk` (wired into the shell) launches `/bin/atk_demo`, letting us exercise the full path end-to-end.
    44	
    45	Two additional userland binaries are now available:
    46	
    47	* `atkshell` launches a graphical shell window backed by the kernels shell session service.
    48	* `taskmgr` opens the ATK Task Manager, showing process and network snapshots gathered via the new syscalls.

payload.message:
**Changes**
- Added a single source of truth for userland surface dirtiness: drawing helpers now call `surface_touch()` so RGB565 buffers stay marked clean unless pixels changed, and new helpers (`video_surface_consume_dirty`, `video_surface_force_dirty`, etc.) expose that state to callers (`user/video_surface.c:16-349`).  
- `atk_user_present()` now short-circuits when no dirty pixels are pending, while `atk_user_present_force()` lets clients push a frame explicitly; failures re-mark the surface so nothing is lost (`user/atk_user.c:27-107`, `user/atk_user.h:17-22`).  
- Kernel-side remote windows coalesce plain mouse-move events before they enter a client queue, preventing cursor jitter from flooding userland while keeping press/release semantics untouched (`src/kernel/user_atk.c:81-650`).  
- Documented the new dirty-present contract and mouse coalescing so future ATK apps know how to opt into forced presents when needed (`docs/user_atk.md:21-34`).

**Verification**
- `make`

**Next Steps**
- 1) Launch `atk_taskmgr` via `make run-hdd` and confirm the cursor no longer flickers while idle over the window; use `killall qemu-system-x86_64` to exit when done.

**Changes**
- Added a single source of truth for userland surface dirtiness: drawing helpers now call `surface_touch()` so RGB565 buffers stay marked clean unless pixels changed, and new helpers (`video_surface_consume_dirty`, `video_surface_force_dirty`, etc.) expose that state to callers (`user/video_surface.c:16-349`).  
- `atk_user_present()` now short-circuits when no dirty pixels are pending, while `atk_user_present_force()` lets clients push a frame explicitly; failures re-mark the surface so nothing is lost (`user/atk_user.c:27-107`, `user/atk_user.h:17-22`).  
- Kernel-side remote windows coalesce plain mouse-move events before they enter a client queue, preventing cursor jitter from flooding userland while keeping press/release semantics untouched (`src/kernel/user_atk.c:81-650`).  
- Documented the new dirty-present contract and mouse coalescing so future ATK apps know how to opt into forced presents when needed (`docs/user_atk.md:21-34`).

**Verification**
- `make`

**Next Steps**
- 1) Launch `atk_taskmgr` via `make run-hdd` and confirm the cursor no longer flickers while idle over the window; use `killall qemu-system-x86_64` to exit when done.

payload.text: **Investigating remote window focus and event handling**

summary.text: **Investigating remote window focus and event handling**

payload.text:
**Analyzing remote window focus and input handling**

Im exploring why the remote window, especially for Doom, loses keyboard focus despite mouse clicks. The key might be that gating `atk_user_present` to only run on dirty frames causes skipped refreshes; Doom may write directly to the buffer without marking it dirty, so the system misses updates. This leads to focus not switching properly because userland isn't signaling activity, and event coalescing might also be affecting how mouse press events trigger focus changes. I need to check how Doom interacts with surface dirty flags and the event flow through `user_atk_focus_window`.

summary.text:
**Analyzing remote window focus and input handling**

Im exploring why the remote window, especially for Doom, loses keyboard focus despite mouse clicks. The key might be that gating `atk_user_present` to only run on dirty frames causes skipped refreshes; Doom may write directly to the buffer without marking it dirty, so the system misses updates. This leads to focus not switching properly because userland isn't signaling activity, and event coalescing might also be affecting how mouse press events trigger focus changes. I need to check how Doom interacts with surface dirty flags and the event flow through `user_atk_focus_window`.

**Analyzing focus and input event handling issues**

There are clues around how `user_atk_focus_window` is invoked only when dispatching to a child widget and possible skips caused by filtering or coalescing mouse events; the kernel focus seems unchanged, so Im digging into when and why `g_focus_window` might get cleared or not set as expected.

payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: docs/user_atk.md
@@
-* `atk_user.c` wraps the UI syscalls. It owns the software surface, exposes `atk_user_window_open`, `atk_user_present`, `atk_user_wait_event`, and `atk_user_close`, and wires the surface into the ATK renderer.
+* `atk_user.c` wraps the UI syscalls. It owns the software surface, exposes `atk_user_window_open`, `atk_user_present`, `atk_user_wait_event`, and `atk_user_close`, and wires the surface into the ATK renderer.
+* ATK-based clients that render via `atk_render()` should call `atk_user_enable_dirty_tracking()` after opening their window; this turns on automatic dirty tracking backed by the software surface so `atk_user_present()` can skip redundant uploads. Apps that paint directly into the buffer (Doom, Wolf3D, etc.) simply omit the call and continue to present every frame.
@@
-* `atk_user_present()` now consults the software surfaces dirty bit and becomes a no-op when no pixels changed, eliminating redundant copies to the kernel. `atk_user_present_force()` is available when a client needs to push the buffer even if nothing was marked dirty (for example after resyncing window contents).
+* `atk_user_present()` consults the software surfaces dirty bit when tracking is enabled and becomes a no-op when no pixels changed, eliminating redundant copies to the kernel. `atk_user_present_force()` is available when a client needs to push the buffer even if nothing was marked dirty (for example after resyncing window contents).
*** End Patch

{"output":"    18	
    19	## Userland Toolkit
    20	
    21	* We compile the ATK sources for userland with `ATK_NO_DESKTOP_APPS` so shared code (window manager, widgets) is available without shell/task-manager dependencies. Rendering helpers (`video_*`) are provided by `user/video_surface.c`, which draws into a software buffer.
    22	* `atk_user.c` wraps the UI syscalls. It owns the software surface, exposes `atk_user_window_open`, `atk_user_present`, `atk_user_wait_event`, and `atk_user_close`, and wires the surface into the ATK renderer.
    23	* ATK-based clients that render via `atk_render()` should call `atk_user_enable_dirty_tracking()` after opening their window; this turns on automatic dirty tracking backed by the software surface so `atk_user_present()` can skip redundant uploads. Apps that paint directly into the buffer (Doom, Wolf3D, etc.) simply omit the call and continue to present every frame.
    24	* Because `video.h` was hard-coded, it now honours `VIDEO_WIDTH`/`VIDEO_HEIGHT` overrides. Userland builds set these constants (currently 640360) so every ATK call uses the same logical surface size that the kernel remote window allocates.
    25	* User apps render exactly like the kernel: they call `atk_render()` after ATK reports a redraw, then push the buffer via `atk_user_present`. Local widgets (text input, label, etc.) behave exactly as they do in kernel space because we instantiate a regular ATK window and slide it upward (negative Y) so the chrome is clipped before blitting into the remote frame.
    26	* `atk_user_present()` consults the software surfaces dirty bit when tracking is enabled and becomes a no-op when no pixels changed, eliminating redundant copies to the kernel. `atk_user_present_force()` is available when a client needs to push the buffer even if nothing was marked dirty (for example after resyncing window contents).
    27	
    28	## Event Model
    29	
    30	Global vs. local responsibilities are split:
    31	
    32	* **Global**: window chrome, z-order, focus changes and capture continue to live in the kernel ATK state. Mouse presses on titles still drag windows, the desktop still receives clicks, etc.
    33	* **Local**: content-space events (mouse within the client area, key presses when the remote window has focus, close notifications) are delivered to the user process via the new syscalls. The user process feeds them into its ATK state (`atk_handle_mouse_event`/`atk_handle_key_char`) and decides when to redraw.
    34	* The kernel coalesces plain mouse-move events per window, so a client only sees the latest coordinates when the pointer is moving without new presses/releases. This keeps queues short and avoids starving UI threads when the pointer is jittery.
    35	
    36	## Demo
    37	
    38	`user/atk_demo.c` is a minimal userland GUI app:
    39	
    40	1. Calls `atk_user_window_open` (title ATK Demo) to create a 640360 remote window.

payload.message:
**Dirty Tracking Rework**
- Made surface-dirty throttling opt-in so apps that blit manually (Doom, Wolf3D, TTF demo) keep presenting every frame while ATK apps still skip redundant uploads. `atk_user_present()` now only short-circuits when a window opts in through `atk_user_enable_dirty_tracking()` and the surface reports no changes (`user/atk_user.c:27-182`, `user/atk_user.h:8-22`).
- Extended the software surface to track whether were in auto-dirty mode; when disabled we treat every frame as dirty so direct buffer writes stay visible (`user/video_surface.c:11-371`, `user/video_surface.h:1-13`). Added helpers to toggle/inspect this state.
- Updated ATK-based clients (demo, shell, task manager) to enable the new tracking right after opening their remote window so they benefit from the reduced copies without impacting games or other custom renderers (`user/atk_demo.c:119-135`, `user/atk_shell_app.c:269-329`, `user/atk_taskmgr_app.c:447-520`).
- Documented the opt-in API so future userland apps know when to turn tracking on (`docs/user_atk.md:21-33`).

**Why Doom Works Again**
- Because dirty tracking now defaults to always present, Dooms software renderer once again pushes every frame, restoring both visuals and input responsiveness (since the window continues to present/focus normally). ATK apps explicitly opt-in, so we still avoid redundant uploads where they mattered.

**Verification**
- `make`

**Next Step**
- Run `make run-hdd`, launch `doom` and an ATK app (e.g., `atk_taskmgr`), and confirm: Doom now responds to WASD, while ATK apps redraw only when their widgets change. Use `killall qemu-system-x86_64` to exit the VM afterwards.

content.text:
**Dirty Tracking Rework**
- Made surface-dirty throttling opt-in so apps that blit manually (Doom, Wolf3D, TTF demo) keep presenting every frame while ATK apps still skip redundant uploads. `atk_user_present()` now only short-circuits when a window opts in through `atk_user_enable_dirty_tracking()` and the surface reports no changes (`user/atk_user.c:27-182`, `user/atk_user.h:8-22`).
- Extended the software surface to track whether were in auto-dirty mode; when disabled we treat every frame as dirty so direct buffer writes stay visible (`user/video_surface.c:11-371`, `user/video_surface.h:1-13`). Added helpers to toggle/inspect this state.
- Updated ATK-based clients (demo, shell, task manager) to enable the new tracking right after opening their remote window so they benefit from the reduced copies without impacting games or other custom renderers (`user/atk_demo.c:119-135`, `user/atk_shell_app.c:269-329`, `user/atk_taskmgr_app.c:447-520`).
- Documented the opt-in API so future userland apps know when to turn tracking on (`docs/user_atk.md:21-33`).

**Why Doom Works Again**
- Because dirty tracking now defaults to always present, Dooms software renderer once again pushes every frame, restoring both visuals and input responsiveness (since the window continues to present/focus normally). ATK apps explicitly opt-in, so we still avoid redundant uploads where they mattered.

**Verification**
- `make`

**Next Step**
- Run `make run-hdd`, launch `doom` and an ATK app (e.g., `atk_taskmgr`), and confirm: Doom now responds to WASD, while ATK apps redraw only when their widgets change. Use `killall qemu-system-x86_64` to exit the VM afterwards.

**Extending task manager with memory tab**

I'm planning to add a new "Memory" tab alongside "Processes" and "Network" in the task manager UI, showing heap usage stats per process. This involves expanding data structures with heap_used and heap_committed fields, updating process snapshot logic to fill those, and refreshing both lists on each update without duplicating snapshots. I also need to create and populate a new list view with five columns to display this memory info, plus update the app struct and initialization accordingly. I'll ensure existing rendering and refresh loops handle the additional list safely. This approach keeps the memory data integrated yet separated in its own tab for clarity.

payload.text:
**Summarizing key changes and next steps**

Im putting together a clear summary that highlights the kernel data additions with file references, the new memory tab in the task manager UI including relevant lines, and notes on `make` build success with pre-existing warnings. Ill also include next steps like running `make run-hdd` and verifying in QEMU to keep everything actionable and organized.

payload.message:
- Added per-process heap reporting to the kernel snapshot plumbing so userland can see `brk` usage: `process_info_t` now tracks used/committed bytes and `process_snapshot` populates them for user tasks (`include/process.h:51-64`, `src/kernel/process.c:3161-3200`). The syscall struct mirrors these fields and `syscall_do_proc_snapshot` copies them, so every `sys_proc_snapshot` call exposes heap stats to clients (`include/syscall_defs.h:50-62`, `src/kernel/syscall.c:61-96`).

- Task Manager now builds a third tab labeled Memory that lists each process alongside heap usage and commit size, populated from the same snapshot as the CPU view (`user/atk_taskmgr_app.c:215-332`, `user/atk_taskmgr_app.c:387-479`). The refresh path reuses one snapshot to update both the original process table and the new memory table, so the data stays consistent and we avoid extra syscalls.

- `make` (with the usual pre-existing warnings about unused helpers in `process.c`); binaries rebuilt, including the updated `atk_taskmgr`.

Next steps: run `make run-hdd`, open Task Manager, and flip between Processes and the new Memory tab to confirm heap figures look sane; close with `killall qemu-system-x86_64` when finished.

The refresh path reuses one snapshot to update both the original process table and the new memory table, so the data stays consistent and we avoid extra syscalls.

payload.text:
**Designing window resizing and cursor integration**

Im mapping out a plan to add window resizing support by detecting cursor proximity to edges, changing cursor shapes for resize hints, and handling resize gestures in both kernel and userland. This involves extending ATK to track resizing state, adding kernel-user events and syscalls for resize notifications, managing pixel buffer reallocations for remote windows, and updating layouts dynamically in user apps while addressing challenges like compile-time video dimension constants. Its a big feature touching input handling, window management, and cross-component communication, so Im breaking it into parts for incremental implementation.

**Designing column and window resizing features**

I'm mapping out a plan to enable column resizing in the list viewespecially for the Task Managerand extending window resizing to handle pixel buffer reallocations safely. This involves adding new state fields, mouse event handling with hit testing for headers and window edges, cursor shape changes, and coordination with the kernel for buffer resizing and event dispatch. I'll also ensure minimum sizes and smooth user interaction by capturing mouse events properly and updating layouts on resize. Theres a lot to coordinate between UI events, internal state, and kernel interactions, but Im excited to put it all together!

**Implementing window resizing mechanics and cursor updates**

Im planning detailed kernel changes to support window resizing with edge detection and cursor shape switching, carefully integrating new state fields and APIs. This includes updating userland components to handle buffer reallocations, synchronizing remote window resizes, and ensuring clean event flow with resize state tracking. The cursor update logic will avoid unnecessary redraws, and window resizing will cleanly coexist with existing drag handling, making the experience smooth and robust.

## My request for Codex:
OK, next, we need to support resizing of userland ATK applications.

This is a complex change, and requires thinking about:

Window-edge resizing drags and cursor change to indicate a window can be resized.

Reallocation of client space for a video surface in a window.

Widget constraints and behaviours to fill the new available space in a window, without hard-coding values.

Whilst we're at it, in Task Manager, also support resizing columns in the list view (as used in task manager)

Got itbig lift. Heres the approach Ill drive:

- Extend ATKs window manager to detect edge hover/drag, show appropriate resize cursors, and emit new resize events. That means cursor-shape plumbing in `video.c`, hit-testing window borders/corners, plus state to track active resize operations (independent from move drags).

- When a resize completes, kernel-side remote-window code must adjust the embedded `atk_image` backing buffer and notify the owning process. Ill add a new syscall/event so userland knows the new client width/height, reallocates its software surface, and calls into ATK to relayout/paint.

- On the userland side, ATK widgets/layouts need to flow with the new window dimensions rather than hard-coded numbers. Ill review `atk_layout`, tab views, list views, etc., and ensure they recompute bounds during `atk_render`. Apps like Task Manager will swap any fixed `width/height` assumptions with layout-driven sizes so content stretches cleanly.

- Finally, Task Managers list views get column-resize support: add mouse hit-testing on header dividers, drag logic that adjusts per-column widths (stored in `atk_list_view_priv_t`), redraw, and maybe persist while switching tabs.

Once Ive crafted the kernel/user API changes and UI behaviour, Ill implement and test via `make` and a manual `make run-hdd` smoke. Let me know if you have specific resize UX requirements or default min sizes you want baked in before I start coding.

- When a resize completes, kernel-side remote-window code must adjust the embedded `atk_image` backing buffer and notify the owning process. Ill add a new syscall/event so userland knows the new client width/height, reallocates its software surface, and calls into ATK to relayout/paint.

- On the userland side, ATK widgets/layouts need to flow with the new window dimensions rather than hard-coded numbers. Ill review `atk_layout`, tab views, list views, etc., and ensure they recompute bounds during `atk_render`. Apps like Task Manager will swap any fixed `width/height` assumptions with layout-driven sizes so content stretches cleanly.

- Finally, Task Managers list views get column-resize support: add mouse hit-testing on header dividers, drag logic that adjusts per-column widths (stored in `atk_list_view_priv_t`), redraw, and maybe persist while switching tabs.

Once Ive crafted the kernel/user API changes and UI behaviour, Ill implement and test via `make` and a manual `make run-hdd` smoke. Let me know if you have specific resize UX requirements or default min sizes you want baked in before I start coding.
